decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of the original permission (ref. 18/14880/FUL). Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any windows or rooflights upon the side elevation adjacent to No.119 (and situated on the first floor) shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and must be replaced in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining premises from overlooking and loss of privacy.

Before the development hereby permitted is first occupied, details of enclosures and screened facilities for the storage of recycling containers and wheeled refuse bins or other refuse storage containers where applicable, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Details should comply with Appendix 2 - Waste Management of the Residential Design (2013) SPD.The development shall be implemented in full accordance with the details as	approved under this condition prior to the first occupation and retained as such thereafter. No refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for	collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance for the development and satisfactory accessibility; and to protect the amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the development hereby permitted is first occupied cycle storage facilities shall be provided to accommodate 4 No. cycle parking spaces in accordance with a scheme to be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The development shall thereafter be implemented in accordance with the details as approved under this condition and the spaces shall be permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure the provision and availability of adequate cycle parking in accordance with Policy DM08 (Sustainable Transport for New Development) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The property shall be used as self-contained units as shown in the hereby approved drawings under Class C3 (a) and no other purpose (including any other purpose in Class C3 or C4 of the Schedule to the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987, or in any provision equivalent to that Class in any statutory instrument revoking and re-enacting that Order, with or without modification).Reason: To enable the Local Planning Authority to exercise control of the type	of use within the category in order to safeguard the amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments	including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the development hereby permitted is commenced, details of wheel washing facilities and the means of site access for construction, as well as an idle vehicle route showing where delivery vehicles can wait should there be no space at site for offloading should be submitted in full to Transport for London. Reason: In the interests of highway safety.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:- The parking of vehicle of site operatives and visitors routes for construction traffic;- Hours of operation;- Highway pedestrian and cyclist protection;- Proposed temporary traffic restrictions;- Arrangements for turning vehicles.Reasons: In the interests of safe operation of the highway in the lead into development both during the demolition and construction phase of the development.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representation has been received.Revelant Planning History21/03351/HOU - Erection of single storey rear extension - Refuse on 12 Jan 2022The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The proposed erection of single storey rear extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would address the previous reasons for refusal, and would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
The applicant is advised to incorporate flood resistance/resilience measures, as the site is within Flood Zone 2.

---Officer Report---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.The application is submitted under Section 192 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to ascertain whether the "Use of part of dwelling to set-up cab company dispatch function from home office" would be lawful for planning purposes.The Letter submitted as part of the application describes the use in more detail -1. Zero Staff:Our business model does not require any staff on the premises. I will be the only one using this office. We will not beemploying any staff from home.2. The majority of our communications/bookings will be via email:Our bookings will be through:a. Websiteb. Our Appc. Emaild. Phone3. We will specialise in contract-based and pre-bookable work only; we will not provide 'ad-hoc' and'impromptu' daily local rides service; we will not have any walk-in customers; no drivers will be required tocome to our premises:a. We will only take bookings which are contract-based (e.g: school-runs) or pre-booked (e.g: airports).b. We will not operate a local rides service nor will we take 'asap daily/on-demand/straight-away bookings'c. We will not require walk-in customers. No customers will be permitted to turn-up to the property. No pick-ups shallbe booked from the office location. This is not our model.b. Due to the above points, it follows that our model will not require any drivers to operate from the site. All our drivers will be operating remotely or from their homes. We will have zero vehicles parked/operating from the site.4. There will be no disturbance or change to the quality of life enjoyed by our neighbours and theneighbourhood as a whole:Our business model does not require any vehicles, customers or drivers on-site, hence there will be zero changes tothe quality of life enjoyed by our neighbours and the neighbourhood. There will be no employees and hence no staffrequired at the office. Nor will we display any business-signs on the property to publicise the office. As far as theoutside world is concerned there will be no change in how the property is used.Based on the information provided by the applicant (see above), the use described would not amount to a material change of use of part or whole of the house and therefore planning permission is not required.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a two storey semi detached dwelling.The front part of the property is located within a Flood Risk Area Zone 2.Proposal The applicant seeks planning permission for demolition of existing rear storage room, erection of single storey rear extension, erection of hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 2no. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversionConsultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. One representation was received objecting to the proposal on the following grounds:Scale and height of the proposed single storey rear extension;Overbearing impact;Loss of light;Lack of detail regarding external treatment of the proposed extension.All of the above will be addressed within this report.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Proposals to extend a hipped roof to a gable roof are not usually appropriate as they are often at odds with the existing character of a property. This is particularly true when proposing to extend the roof of a semi detached property, which would upset the visual balance of the two houses, much like the application site. However, Officers have had regard to the fallback position (which is a material planning consideration) of permitted development rights under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class B of The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 2015, which would allow for a hip to gable roof conversion as proposed to be constructed without notifying the local planning authority. In addition, a number of neighbouring properties in the immediate vicinity have constructed a hip to gable roof extension. As such, this element of the proposal is unlikely to have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.  Officers also note an application to modify the roof of the neighbouring and adjoining property has recently been submitted. The proposed single storey rear and side extension would be located along the shared boundary and whilst of an acceptable height, would be 5.7m in depth exceeding the Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. Officers note there are other larger single storey rear extensions in the vicinity of the property, but also that the neighbouring property has not been extended.External details of the proposed works have been shown and would be in keeping with the host dwelling.Having regard to the above officers consider that the proposed development would not appear disproportionate to the host dwellinghouse and would have an acceptable impact on its appearance. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The proposed development would maintain the existing setback from the shared boundary with No.53 Egmont Road and given the siting and design unlikely to have any adverse impact on the amenities of this property. The proposed single storey rear extension would project 5.7m beyond the rear of No.49 Egmont Road. The excessive depth of the proposed single storey rear extension, and its siting along the shared boundary would have an overbearing appearance and result in an undue sense of enclosure to adjoining property, No.49 Egmont Road. The applicant has also failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed single storey rear extension would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the closest ground floor principal habitable room window at No.49 Egmont Road in terms of daylight/sunlight. It is therefore considered that it would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring property by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light  or loss of privacy.Flood Risk Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: As set out above, the application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk documentation states details flood proofing measures which are considered satisfactory and in compliance with policy SI.12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be contradictory with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Mill Street. The site is situated within Flood Zone 2, a Controlled Parking Zone, as well as the Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area, and finally the Kingston Town Centre Area of Archaeological Significance.  Planning History93/0554/LDP - Erection of conservatory to rear (LDC) (P). Application Granted on 15 Jun 199322/01727/HOU - Erection of rear dormer roof extension with installation of 2no rear and 1no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Associated changes to fenestration. Pending consideration. Consultations13 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.Kingston Town Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee - No objection. Historic England (Archaeology) - Proposal is unlikely to have a significant effect onheritage assets of archaeological interestConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on drainage. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension, as well as the installation of one window on the side elevation of the original dwellinghouse. Whilst the materials of the proposed extension would not be of a similar appearance to those used in the construction of the dwellinghouse, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Nevertheless, Officers consider it appropriate to add a condition to the permission in the event of an approval to ensure that the proposed window in the side elevation of the main dwelling above first floor level is installed as obscure glazed and maintained thereafter. Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Officers Comments: The site is located within the Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area. This is a designated heritage asset. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be described as: An early suburb of Kingston Town Centre comprising houses of various sizes and designs dating mainly from the 1820s to 1900 around Fairfield, a recreational open space since 1855. As the proposed development is considered to have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area, officers subsequently consider that the proposal would not harm the architectural and historic significance of the Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area. Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officers Comments: The site is located within Flood Zone 2, which has a medium probability of flooding. The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 8 (Basement Impact Assessment) of planning permission 21/01585/FUL, which states:Condition 8 (Basement Impact Assessment) of planning permission 21/01585/FUL - Prior to the commencement of any excavation or subterranean development, a basement impact assessment shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The documents shall consider:a. The methodology for constructing the basementb. The impact of the development on the risk of flooding from all sources, bothto the site itself and elsewherec. The impact of the development on surface water drainaged. The impact of the development on land stabilityThe development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
